case_name: Ratan Lal v. State of Maharashtra

facts.text: Ratan Lal is the proprietor of a business in drugs styled Anil Medical Stores at Wani, District Yeotmal in the State of Maharashtra.

anchor.surface_text: Ratan Lal-appellant in this appeal-is the pro- prietor of a business in drugs styled Anil Medical Stores at Wani, District Yeotmal in the State of Maharashtra.

facts.text: On September 14, 1960 the Station House Officer, Wani, raided the shop of the appellant and seized 12 bottles of Mahadrakshasava manufactured by Brahma Aushadhalaya, Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: On September 14, 1960 the Station House Officer, Wani, raided the shop of the appellant and seized 12 bottles of an Ayurvedic preparation called Mahadrakshasva manufactured by the Brahma Aushadhalaya, Nagpur

facts.text: 88 bottles of Dashmoolarishta manufactured by the Vedic Pharmaceutical Works, Nagpur were seized from the appellant's shop.

anchor.surface_text: and 88 bottles of Dashmoolarishta manufactured by the Vedic Pharmaceutical Works, Nagpur. At a trial held before the Magistrate, First Class, Kalapur, the appellant was companyvicted of the offence punishable under s. 66 1  b  of the Bombay Prohibition Act 25 of 1949, and was sentenced to suffer rigorous imprisonment for three months and to pay a fine of Rs. 500/-

facts.text: Appellant was convicted by Magistrate, First Class, Kalapur under s. 66(1)(b) of Bombay Prohibition Act 1949, sentenced to 3 months rigorous imprisonment and Rs. 500 fine.

anchor.surface_text: At a trial held before the Magistrate, First Class, Kalapur, the appellant was companyvicted of the offence punishable under s. 66 1  b  of the Bombay Prohibition Act 25 of 1949, and was sentenced to suffer rigorous imprisonment for three months and to pay a fine of Rs. 500/-

facts.text: Conviction confirmed in appeal by Court of Session, Yeotmal.

anchor.surface_text: . The order was companyfirmed in appeal by the Court of Session, Yeotmal. The High Court of Bombay companyfirmed the companyviction, but modified the sentence.

facts.text: Bombay High Court confirmed conviction but modified sentence on August 9, 1963 in Criminal Revision Application No. 107 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 9, 1963 of the Bombay High Court  Nagpur Bench  in Criminal Revision Application No. 107 of 1963.

facts.text: Mahadrakshasava contained 52.3% alcohol v/v and Dashmoolarishta contained 54.5% alcohol v/v.

anchor.surface_text: Mahadrakshasava attached from the shop of the appellant companytained 52.3 alcohol v v and Dashmoolarishta companytained 54.5 alcohol v v.

facts.text: Preparations manufactured by process of distillation under licences under Medicinal and Toilet Preparations Excise Duties Act 1955.

anchor.surface_text: These preparations are manufactured by a process of distillation. The appellant had purchased these preparations from a drug store in Nagpur called the Sharda Medical Stores who in their turn were supplied by the manufacturers the Brahma Aushadhalaya, Nagpur and the Vedic Pharmaceutical Works, Nagpur.

facts.text: Appellant purchased preparations from Sharda Medical Stores in Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had purchased these preparations from a drug store in Nagpur called the Sharda Medical Stores who in their turn were supplied by the manufacturers the Brahma Aushadhalaya, Nagpur and the Vedic Pharmaceutical Works, Nagpur.

facts.text: Lower courts held preparations were fermented with alcohol exceeding 12% by volume, not complying with s.59A.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court held that the offending articles were Ayurvedic preparations in which alcohol was generated by a process of fermentation and as alcohol exceeded 12 per cent by volume, the preparations did number companyrespond with the limitations prescribed by S. 59A

facts.text: Evidence showed preparations manufactured by distillation, not fermentation; conceded by State before Session Court and High Court.

anchor.surface_text: there was on the record clear evidence that the offending preparations were manufactured by a process of distillation and were number preparations in which alcohol was generated by fermentation. Palnitkar, Sub-Inspector of Prohibition Excise, said that Mahadrakshasava and Dashmoolarishta are distilled Ayurvedic products.

facts.text: Preparations manufactured within Maharashtra by licensed manufacturers and issued from bonded warehouse.

anchor.surface_text: It must be remembered that these preparation were manufactured within the State of Maharashtra by manufacturers licensed under the Medicinal and Toilet Preparations  Excise Duties  Act 16 of 1955 and were issued from a bonded warehouse.

facts.text: Government of Maharashtra issued declaration on October 4, 1960 declaring Mahadrakshasava and Dashmoolarishta fit for use as intoxicating liquor after consulting Board of Experts.

anchor.surface_text: After companysulting the Board of Ex- perts the Government of Maharashtra issued a declaration on October 4, 1960, declaring that both the preparations Mahadrakshasava and Dashmoolarishta were medicines fit for use as intoxicating liquor.

facts.text: Police report filed on June 2, 1962 charging appellant under s.66(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter a police report was filed in the Court of the Magistrate, First Class, on June 2, 1962 charging the appellant with the offence under s. 66 1  b  of the Bombay Prohibition Act.

facts.text: Bombay Prohibition Act amended by Act 22 of 1960 brought into force on April 20, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: By Act 22 of 1960, which was brought into force on April 20, 1960, the Bombay Legislature amended, inter alia, sub-s.  6  of S. 6A

facts.text: Appellant possessed preparations without licence, permit or authorization.

anchor.surface_text: it is number the case of the appellant that he was protected by a licence, permit, pass or authorization. His case was that possession of the preparations by him was number in companytravention of the Act

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 53 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 9, 1963

facts.text: Palnitkar, Sub-Inspector of Prohibition Excise, stated that Mahadrakshasava and Dashmoolarishta are distilled Ayurvedic products.

anchor.surface_text: Palnitkar, Sub-Inspector of Prohibition Excise, said that Mahadrakshasava and Dashmoolarishta are distilled Ayurvedic products.

facts.text: State conceded before Court of Session and High Court that preparations contained alcohol produced by distillation.

anchor.surface_text: Apparently it was companyceded on behalf of the State before the Court of session that the two preparation were Ayurvedic medicinal preparations which companytained alcohol produced by distillation, and before the High Court also the case was argued on that footing.

facts.text: At time of seizure on September 14, 1960, preparations deemed unfit for use as intoxicating liquor under s.6A(7).

anchor.surface_text: But on the date on which the medicinal preparations were attached, the statute had provided that they shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act as articles unfit for use as intoxicating liquor.

facts.text: Subsequent declaration on October 4, 1960 has no retrospective effect.

anchor.surface_text: A subsequent declaration by the State that they were fit for use as intoxicating liquor, companyld number have any retrospective operation, and possession which was innocent companyld number, by subsequent act of the State, be declared as offending the statute.

anchor.surface_text: Intoxicant is defined by S. 2  22  as meaning any liquor, intoxicating drug, opium or any other substance, which the State Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette declare to be an intoxicant. Liquor is defined in S. 2 24  as including

Liquor is defined in S. 2 24  as including  a  spirits denatured spirits, wine, beer, toddy and all liquids consisting of or containing alcohol  b  any other intoxicating substance which the State Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette, declare to be liquor
Section 12 of the Act, insofar as it is material, provides that no person shall import, export, transport or possess liquor. But these prohibitions are subject to certain exceptions.

concepts.unlisted_description: Prohibits possession of liquor subject to exceptions

anchor.surface_text: By S. 11 notwithstanding anything contained in the provisions contained in Ch. III  which includes ss. 11 to 24-A  it is lawful to import, export, transport, manufacture, sell, buy, possess, use or consume any intoxicant to the extent provided by the provisions of the Act or any rules

anchor.surface_text: Nothing in this Chapter shall be deemed to apply to Any toilet preparation containing alcohol which is unfit for use as intoxicating liquor  2  any medicinal preparation containing alcohol which is unfit for use as intoxicating liquor  3  any antiseptic preparation or solution containing alcohol which is unfit for use as intoxicating liquor  4  any flavouring extract, essence or syrup containing alcohol which is unfit for use as intoxicating liquor Provided that such article corresponds with the description and limitations mentioned in section 59A

concepts.interpretation: Exempts possession of medicinal preparations containing alcohol if unfit for use as intoxicating liquor and complies with s.59A; appellant claimed protection under this

anchor.surface_text: No manufacturer of any of the articles mentioned in section 24A shall sell, use or dispose of any liquor purchased or possessed for the purposes of such manufacture under the provisions of this Act otherwise than as an ingredient of the articles authorised to be manufactured therefrom. No more alcohol shall be used in the manufacture of any of the articles mentioned in section 24A than the quantity necessary for extraction or solution of the elements contained therein and for the preservation of the articles Provided that in the case of manufacture of any of the articles mentioned in section 24A in which the alcohol is generated by a process of fermentation the amount of such alcohol shall not exceed 12 per cent by volume.

concepts.interpretation: Limits alcohol in medicinal preparations: for fermentation <=12% v/v; for distillation/addition, only necessary quantity; lower courts erred applying fermentation proviso, evidence shows distillation so proviso inapplicable and licensed manufacture implies compliance

issues.text: The question which falls to be determined in this appeal is whether the preparations containing alcohol in respect of which the appellant is convicted were medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor.

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls to be determined in this appeal is whether the preparations containing alcohol in respect of which the appellant is convicted were medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. That the preparations were medicinal according to the Ayurvedic system is not denied, and it is common ground that they contained alcohol.

issues.text: whether the preparations did correspond with the description and limitations mentioned in s. 59A

anchor.surface_text: Attention must therefore be directed to ascertain whether the preparations did correspond with the description and limitations mentioned in s. 59A. If they did not, exemption under S. 24-A will be inoperative, even if they are medi- cinal preparations.

issues.text: whether the offending preparations were manufactured by a process of distillation and were not preparations in which alcohol was generated by fermentation

anchor.surface_text: the Courts misconceived the evidence. Articles containing alcohol may be prepared by a process of fermentation which generates alcohol or by a process of distillation or by addition of free alcohol. The manufacturing processes which result in distillation of alcohol and generation of alcohol by fermentation are distinct, and there was on the record clear evidence that the offending preparations were manufactured by a process of distillation and were not preparations in which alcohol was generated by fermentation.

issues.text: whether under the amended S. 6A there is only one mode of proof by the State that an article is fit for use as intoxicating liquor

anchor.surface_text: Under the amended S. 6A there is only one mode of proof by the State that an article is fit for use as intoxicating liquor, and that is by obtaining the advice of the Board of Experts and recording its determination, that the article is fit for use as intoxicating liquor.

issues.text: whether on the date on which the medicinal preparations were attached, the statute had provided that they shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act as articles unfit for use as intoxicating liquor

anchor.surface_text: But on the date on which the medicinal preparations were attached, the statute had provided that they shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act as articles unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. Possession of the medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor was, at the date when they were attached, not an offence.

issues.text: whether a subsequent declaration by the State that they were fit for use as intoxicating liquor, could have any retrospective operation

anchor.surface_text: A subsequent declaration by the State that they were fit for use as intoxicating liquor, could not have any retrospective operation, and possession which was innocent could not, by subsequent act of the State, be declared as offending the statute.

arguments.claim: Possession of the preparations by him was not in contravention of the Act, because the preparations were medicinal preparations containing alcohol which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor within the meaning of s. 24A of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The appellant did at the material time possess preparations which contained a large percentage of alcohol, and it is not the case of the appellant that he was protected by a licence, permit, pass or authorization. His case was that possession of the preparations by him was not in contravention of the Act, because the preparations were medicinal preparations containing alcohol which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor within the meaning of s. 24A of the Act.

arguments.claim: Offending preparations manufactured by process of distillation not fermentation; proviso to s.59A inapplicable

anchor.surface_text: But it appears that in so holding, the Courts misconceived the evidence. Articles containing alcohol may be prepared by a process of fermentation which generates alcohol or by a process of distillation or by addition of free alcohol.

arguments.claim: No evidence preparations contained alcohol in excess of quantity permissible under first paragraph of s.59A; licensed under Medicinal Act and issued from bonded warehouse justifies inference of compliance

anchor.surface_text: There is no evidence on the record to prove that the two preparations contained alcohol in excess of the quantity permissible under the first paragraph of S. 59A. It must be remembered that these preparation were manufactured within the State of Maharashtra by manufacturers licensed under the Medicinal and Toilet Preparations Excise Duties Act 16 of 1955

arguments.claim: Under amended s.6A, only one mode of proof by State that article fit for intoxicating liquor: advice of Board and State determination

anchor.surface_text: Under the amended S. 6A there is only one mode of proof by the State that an article is fit for use as intoxicating liquor, and that is by obtaining the advice of the Board of Experts and recording its determination, that the article is fit for use as intoxicating liquor.

arguments.claim: Until State determines fit under s.6A(7), every such article deemed unfit for intoxicating use

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of s. 6A has by the amending Act been completely altered. The Legislature has prescribed by sub-s. 7 that until the State Government has determined any article mentioned in sub-s. 1 to be fit for use as intoxicating liquor, every such article, shall be deemed to be unfit for such use.

arguments.claim: On date of seizure, no State determination; preparations deemed unfit; possession not offence

anchor.surface_text: But on the date on which the medicinal preparations were attached, the statute had provided that they shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act as articles unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. Possession of the medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor was, at the date when they were attached, not an offence.

arguments.claim: Subsequent State declaration no retrospective operation; cannot criminalize prior innocent possession

anchor.surface_text: A subsequent declaration by the State that they were fit for use as intoxicating liquor, could not have any retrospective operation, and possession which was innocent could not, by subsequent act of the State, be declared as offending the statute.

arguments.claim: Narandas Mangilal case not applicable post-amendment of s.6A; scheme altered by sub-s.7 deeming provision

anchor.surface_text: It is unfortunate that the High Court lost sight of the change in the scheme of S. 6A and followed the judgment of this Court in Narandas Mangilals case. In Narandas Mangilals case at all material times when the question fell to be considered, the Court had to decide whether sub-s. 6 of S. 6A,

holdings.text: The preparations containing alcohol were medicinal preparations unfit for use as intoxicating liquor within s.24A, as they complied with s.59A and were deemed unfit under s.6A(7) at the time of possession.

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls to be determined in this appeal is whether the preparations containing alcohol in respect of which the appellant is convicted were medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. That the preparations were medicinal according to the Ayurvedic system is not denied, and it is common ground that they contained alcohol.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preparations medicinal and alcoholic; complied with s.59A limits via distillation and licensing; deemed unfit pre-determination under amended s.6A(7).

holdings.text: The preparations corresponded with the description and limitations in s.59A.

anchor.surface_text: It must be remembered that these preparation were manufactured within the State of Maharashtra by manufacturers licensed under the Medicinal and Toilet Preparations  Excise Duties  Act 16 of 1955 and were issued from a bonded warehouse. This would justify the inference that they did correspond with the description and limitations mentioned in S. 59A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of excess alcohol; licensed manufacture under MTP Act and bonded warehouse issuance infers compliance; distillation process excludes fermentation proviso.

holdings.text: The preparations were manufactured by distillation, not fermentation; proviso to s.59A(1) inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: But it appears that in so holding, the Courts misconceived the evidence. Articles containing alcohol may be prepared by a process of fermentation which generates alcohol or by a process of distillation or by addition of free alcohol. The manufacturing processes which result in distillation of alcohol and generation of alcohol by fermentation are distinct, and there was on the record clear evidence that the offending preparations were manufactured by a process of distillation and were not preparations in which alcohol was generated by fermentation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear record evidence including witness testimony; conceded by State in lower courts; distinguishes manufacturing processes.

holdings.text: Under amended s.6A, only mode of proof for State that article fit for intoxicating use is Board advice and State determination.

anchor.surface_text: Under the amended S. 6A there is only one mode of proof by the State that an article is fit for use as intoxicating liquor, and that is by obtaining the advice of the Board of Experts and recording its determination, that the article is fit for use as intoxicating liquor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amended scheme alters pre-1960 law; sub-s.(6) creates rebuttable presumption post-determination; exclusive proof method post-amendment.

holdings.text: At date of attachment (Sept 14, 1960), preparations deemed unfit under s.6A(7); possession not offence.

anchor.surface_text: But on the date on which the medicinal preparations were attached, the statute had provided that they shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act as articles unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. Possession of the medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor was, at the date when they were attached, not an offence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No prior State determination; s.6A(7) deeming provision applies until determination; defines fitness for s.24A.

holdings.text: State declaration under s.6A(6) has no retrospective operation; cannot criminalise prior innocent possession.

anchor.surface_text: A subsequent declaration by the State that they were fit for use as intoxicating liquor, could not have any retrospective operation, and possession which was innocent could not, by subsequent act of the State, be declared as offending the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deeming provision prospective; post-seizure declaration (Oct 4, 1960) does not affect earlier status.

holdings.text: Narandas Mangilal not applicable post-1960 amendment; s.6A(7) deeming provision changes scheme from mere evidence rule.

anchor.surface_text: It is unfortunate that the High Court lost sight of the change in the scheme of S. 6A and followed the judgment of this Court in Narandas Mangilals case. In Narandas Mangilals case at all material times when the question fell to be considered, the Court had to decide whether sub-s. 6 of S. 6A,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-amendment allowed aliunde proof; amendment introduces deeming till determination, distinguishing prior precedent.

Narandas Mangilal Agarwal Another 1 that it was number obligatory upon the State to companysult the Board of Experts companystituted under s. 6A before the State companyld establish in a prosecution for an offence under S. 66 1  b  that a medicinal preparation was unfit for use as intoxicating liquor.

precedents.cited_proposition: it was not obligatory upon the State to consult the Board of Experts constituted under s. 6A before the State could establish in a prosecution for an offence under S. 66(1)(b) that a medicinal preparation was unfit for use as intoxicating liquor

The State of Bombay 2 wherein the High Court had held that the prosecution for offence under ss. 65 and 66 companyld number be maintained unless the State Government was satisfied after companysulting the Board of Experts under S. 6A that the article was fit to be used as intoxicating liquor.

precedents.cited_proposition: the prosecution for offence under ss. 65 and 66 could not be maintained unless the State Government was satisfied after consulting the Board of Experts under S. 6A that the article was fit to be used as intoxicating liquor

anchor.surface_text: The offence in Narandas Mangilals case 1 was companymitted in July 1955 and on the terms of sub-s.  6  as it then stood it was open to the State in a prosecution for infringement of a prohibition companytained in ss. 12 and 13 to rely upon the presumption under S. 6A or to establish that the medicinal preparation was fit for use as intoxicating liquor aliunde.

anchor.surface_text: It is unfortunate that the High Court lost sight of the change in the scheme of S. 6A and followed the judgment of this Court in Narandas Mangilals case 1 . anchor.surface_text: But on the date on which the medicinal preparations were attached, the statute had provided that they shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act as articles unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. Possession of the medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor was, at the date when they were attached, number an offence. anchor.surface_text: The question which falls to be determined in this appeal is whether the preparations containing alcohol in respect of which the appellant is convicted were medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. That the preparations were medicinal according to the Ayurvedic system is not denied, and it is common ground that they contained alcohol.

But on the date on which the medicinal preparations were attached, the statute had provided that they shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act as articles unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. Possession of the medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor was, at the date when they were attached, number an offence. A subsequent declaration by the State that they were fit for use as intoxicating liquor, companyld number have any retrospective operation, and possession which was innocent companyld number, by subsequent act of the State, be declared as offending the statute.
icle in which alcohol is added or produced by distillation is determined by what is necessary for extraction, or solution of the elements, and preserv

anchor.surface_text: It must be remembered that these preparation were manufactured within the State of Maharashtra by manufacturers licensed under the Medicinal and Toilet Preparations  Excise Duties  Act 16 of 1955 and were issued from a bonded warehouse. This would justify the inference that they did correspond with the description and limitations mentioned in S. 59A.

But on the date on which the medicinal preparations were attached, the statute had provided that they shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act as articles unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. Possession of the medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor was, at the date when they were attached, number an offence. A subsequent declaration by the State that they were fit for use as intoxicating liquor, companyld number have any retrospective operation, and possession which was innocent companyld number, by subsequent act of the State, be declared as offending the statute.
hether an article is unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. Section 6A was added by Bombay -Act 26 of 1952 after this Court declared in, The State of B

edges.explanation: Proviso inapplicable undercuts fermentation aspect of c9

anchor.surface_text: hether an article is unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. Section 6A was added by Bombay -Act 26 of 1952 after this Court declared in, The State of B

edges.explanation: Same starting span: holding on distillation addresses i3

anchor.surface_text: But it appears that in so holding, the Courts misconceived the evidence. Articles containing alcohol may be prepared by a process of fermentation which generates alcohol or by a process of distillation or by addition of free alcohol. The manufacturing processes which result in distillation of alcohol and generation of alcohol by fermentation are distinct, and there was on the record clear evidence that the offending preparations were manufactured by a process of distillation and were not preparations in which alcohol was generated by fermentation.

But on the date on which the medicinal preparations were attached, the statute had provided that they shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act as articles unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. Possession of the medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor was, at the date when they were attached, number an offence. A subsequent declaration by the State that they were fit for use as intoxicating liquor, companyld number have any retrospective operation, and possession which was innocent companyld number, by subsequent act of the State, be declared as offending the statute.

anchor.surface_text: Under the amended S. 6A there is only one mode of proof by the State that an article is fit for use as intoxicating liquor, and that is by obtaining the advice of the Board of Experts and recording its determination, that the article is fit for use as intoxicating liquor.

But on the date on which the medicinal preparations were attached, the statute had provided that they shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act as articles unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. Possession of the medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor was, at the date when they were attached, number an offence. A subsequent declaration by the State that they were fit for use as intoxicating liquor, companyld number have any retrospective operation, and possession which was innocent companyld number, by subsequent act of the State, be declared as offending the statute.

anchor.surface_text: A subsequent declaration by the State that they were fit for use as intoxicating liquor, could not have any retrospective operation, and possession which was innocent could not, by subsequent act of the State, be declared as offending the statute.

But on the date on which the medicinal preparations were attached, the statute had provided that they shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act as articles unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. Possession of the medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor was, at the date when they were attached, number an offence. A subsequent declaration by the State that they were fit for use as intoxicating liquor, companyld number have any retrospective operation, and possession which was innocent companyld number, by subsequent act of the State, be declared as offending the statute.

Possession of the medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor was, at the date when they were attached, number an offence.
